instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1278: What is A1278? A1278 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook or Macbook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2254, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2327, 820-2530, 820-2879, 820-2936, 820-3115..
definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.R7402: What is R7402? Resistor between PPVIN_S0_CPUIMVP and CPUIMVP_TON. TON stands for TIME ON â€“ CPUIMVP_TON configures the buck converter for the CPU based on its input power supply. If this resistor is blown, the machine will turn on but not have any image, chime, or POST, because CPU vcore will be missing. This resistor is often the first to corrode because it is along a high voltage rail and it is right on the edge of the board, check this on 2011-2012 model Macbook Pros that turn on and do not chime. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2011 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing CPU vcore
threads.message:
hi

got a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board. board got liquid spilled.some or bit on <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> <TRANSISTOR>Q5030</TRANSISTOR> <RESISTOR>R7551</RESISTOR> ( those areas)

board power up but missing CPU VCORE.

checked on <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> PIN1 VRON 3.3V PIN2 0.5  PIN 40,24, 15   are around 5v

should be good to go , but no CPU VCORE,replaced U 7400,<TRANSISTOR>Q7550</TRANSISTOR> <TRANSISTOR>Q7520</TRANSISTOR> already. same thing

one hint i found out was diode mode on pin 1 <RESISTOR>R7555</RESISTOR> was "0" , i measured on another board is around 500-600.
so i think either <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> or <TRANSISTOR>Q7520</TRANSISTOR> is bad, i replaced both. then checked, back to normal around 500-600

but once i connect power, no CPU vcore, then disconnect charger. check again later, back to "0"

kind of confused with that and stuck now

any advice would be appreciated!
thank you!

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2011 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing CPU vcore
threads.message: Replace <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>. There was of course nothing wrong with <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> and the rest you replaced. Check <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR> too
